Is there a limit on how many users can be on a PM thread?

I don't believe there is. We could probably pretty easily query the database to find out the max number of users anybody has ever put on a PM, and then start enforcing a limit based on that. Mass group-PMs are almost always a bad idea, for the same reason that group texts are.

There's actually a denial-of-service that you can do with group huddles, where you make every possible huddle from a big org like czo and fill up our database. It's not a super practical attack, because we rate-limit message-sends, and you can only introduce one huddle into the database per message. But I think a sane limit would be helpful here for many reasons.
Should I file an issue for the PM limit investigation?
Hrm, I'd ask Tim. It's not a perfect thing for a GH issue, since it requires DB access.

This topic has multiple elements, but I wanted to highlight that we've discussed a future design along these lines for ZT. For us we've likely have P switch to "open/switch to PM list", and ideally migrate S to be the equivalent for streams (instead of changing narrow, and remove s for use elsewhere, given the use of z in ZT). I think as an incremental step, we can certainly do a "Group PMs" icon. However, one of our design principles is for Zulip to be effective to use from the keyboard without reaching for a mouse and certainly without hovering over several elements in sequence, and so important information (which group it is) that's only apparent after hovering isn't ideal. That said, the number is only a partial signal for that, and medium-term we're probably going to look at something like showing 2 lines of names for group PMs, which may be a better path for that anyway.

This will fix the problem that "Group PMs are really hard to distinguish from 1:1 PMs if names are really long in your culture", which is the bigger problem here, and we can iterate from there.
